title: R41239
content: The Eurozone consists of EU countries using the euro as their currency, introduced in 1999. It originally had 11 countries and now includes 16. Greece joined in 2000. Current members are Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, and Spain. Some EU members like Denmark, Sweden, and the UK opted out. New EU entrants must adopt the euro eventually. The Eurozone requires member states to meet economic policy targets, including staying below a government budget deficit ceiling of 3% of GDP and an external debt ceiling of 60% of GDP. Enforcement by EU authorities has been weak, leading to many governments exceeding these limits. Concerns were raised about the viability of an economic union with a common monetary policy but diverse national fiscal policies when the euro was introduced. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) was created after World War II to promote exchange rate and monetary stability. The IMF was established after World War II to promote monetary stability. It provides technical assistance to member countries on banking and finance issues, but its main function is lending money to help countries deal with financial crises. The IMF is owned by member countries, who contribute funds based on their subscribed amounts. Loans are given in phases to encourage compliance with reform measures. The IMF lends money to countries in phases to promote compliance with reform measures. Loans have a repayment period of five to eight years and are charged at an interest rate similar to what major governments pay. Developing countries are now the main borrowers, but during the recent financial crisis, the IMF also lent to newer EU members and countries with advanced economies. Greece heavily borrowed in international markets to fund deficits due to high government spending, weak revenue collection, and loss of competitiveness. Access to low-interest rates after adopting the euro and weak enforcement of EU rules on debt ceilings contributed to the debt accumulation. Investor confidence wavered in 2009 when Greece nearly doubled its budget deficit estimate, leading to austerity measures and bond sales to address the crisis. In late April 2010, Greece's debt crisis escalated as bond spreads spiked and credit rating agencies downgraded Greek bonds. The Greek government sought financial assistance from the Eurozone and the IMF to prevent debt restructuring or default. On May 2, 2010, a financial assistance package was announced to address the crisis. On May 2, 2010, the Eurozone and IMF announced a €110 billion financial assistance package for Greece, with €80 billion from Eurozone countries and €30 billion from the IMF. Germany and France pledged the largest bilateral loans. The IMF and Eurozone member states committed €110 billion for Greece, disbursed in phases as Greece meets loan conditions. If conditions are not met, disbursements will not be made. Some economists predict the package may not prevent debt restructuring or Greece exiting the Eurozone. Half of the IMF loan will be financed by IMF quota resources. The IMF loan to Greece will be partially financed by IMF quota resources, based on member countries' relative size in the world economy. The specific countries contributing to the loan are decided by the IMF Executive Board. The remaining portion of the loan will come from bilateral loans, which will be integrated into the IMF's New Arrangements to Borrow fund. The United States has committed $100 billion to the IMF's New Arrangements to Borrow fund, but it cannot be used for Greece's package until the expanded NAB is operational. U.S. financial interactions with the IMF do not impact the federal budget deficit. IMF loans have priority repayment status over other creditors, including European countries. The IMF has preferred creditor status, meaning it is first in line to be repaid by member countries ahead of other creditors. The risk from lending to Greece is shared among all IMF members, with no historical losses experienced. IMF loans have priority repayment status over other creditors, including European countries. The IMF has preferred creditor status, ensuring repayment ahead of other creditors. Loans are divided into tranches, disbursed based on policy reforms. The IMF program for Greece aims to reduce government deficit from 13.6% to below 3% of GDP by 2014, requiring substantial spending cuts and revenue increases. Some key reforms in Greece's IMF program were crucial for German Chancellor Merkel's financial assistance. IMF conditionality provided impetus for reform and acted as a scapegoat for unpopular policies. IMF's independence and experience in debt crises were valued over the EU's involvement. IMF participation facilitated Eurozone agreement on loan terms. IMF's loan to Greece followed a standard program for countries in need of balance-of-payment support. The IMF loan to Greece followed a standard program for countries with balance-of-payment difficulties. Greece's program with the IMF is unique due to the rarity of IMF lending to developed countries and Eurozone members. IMF has had programs with European countries in the past, but recent involvement has been limited. The IMF had programs with the United Kingdom, Spain, Italy, and Portugal in the 1970s and early 1980s. Greece's program with the IMF is unique for its large loan amount, exceeding IMF limits at 3,200% of Greece's quota. IMF quotas are based on member countries' relative size in the world economy. Greece's IMF program is exceptional with access at 3,200% of its quota, the largest ever granted to a member country. The country is tackling its debt crisis through austerity measures and reforms, supported by financial assistance from the Eurozone and IMF. Some economists suggest Greece may need to restructure its debt or leave the Eurozone in the future. Debt restructuring could alleviate immediate pressure on Greek debt payments, but may spread crisis to other Eurozone countries. Leaving the Eurozone would involve issuing a new national currency and could spur export-led growth in Greece. The possibility of Greece leaving the Eurozone to adopt a depreciated national currency raises concerns about the impact on debt value, contagion to other European countries, and political relations. Investor worries about Eurozone debt sustainability led to a global stock market plunge and a decrease in the euro's value in May 2010. On May 6, 2010, stock markets plunged sharply and the euro fell to a 15-month low against the dollar. EU finance ministers agreed on May 9, 2010, to a €500 billion financial assistance package to prevent contagion to vulnerable Eurozone countries. The move was seen as urgent to break the momentum of the European financial crisis. Global stock markets rebounded on May 10, 2010, in response to the announcement, with the assistance primarily provided through the European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF). The EU established the European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF) and the European Financial Stability Mechanism (EFSM) to provide financial assistance to Eurozone and EU member states facing financial difficulties. The EFSF can offer up to €440 billion in loans, while the EFSM can provide up to €60 billion. Additionally, EU leaders suggested the IMF could contribute an additional €220 billion to €250 billion. No country has utilized these facilities yet. The IMF could contribute an additional €220 billion to €250 billion for Eurozone stabilization efforts, with two-thirds from Eurozone states and one-third from the IMF. The ECB announced it would buy member state bonds to boost market confidence, holding around €60 billion as of July 20, 2010. The ECB held around €60 billion of European government bonds as of July 20, 2010. The Federal Reserve announced swap lines with several central banks, including the ECB, to swap dollars for foreign currencies with no exchange rate or credit risk involved for the Fed. The Federal Reserve provides swap lines to foreign central banks to offer dollar liquidity without credit risk. These lines aim to assist banks in obtaining non-domestic currency liquidity, especially when private inter-bank lending markets are limited during crises. The highest outstanding amount reached $583 billion in December 2008. In April 2009, the G-20 Leaders and the International Monetary and Financial Committee agreed to increase resources available to the IMF through immediate bilateral financing from members and to expand the NAB. As of July 15, 2010, the IMF has about $225.5 billion immediately available to lend, including unused quota resources, bilateral loans, and note purchase agreements with emerging-market countries. The expanded NAB is not yet operational. The New Arrangements to Borrow (NAB) was created in the late 1990s as a supplemental fund for the IMF to provide financing under exceptional circumstances. In April 2009, the G-20 proposed expanding and making the NAB more flexible due to increased demand for IMF assistance. After negotiations, the IMF Executive Board approved expanding the NAB to $550 billion with 13 new participating countries, including a $100 billion commitment from the U.S. However, the expanded NAB is not yet operational as formal consent from participants is still needed. The expanded NAB requires formal consent from participants before becoming operational. Approval procedures in many countries, including legislative approval, are necessary. The IMF has not disclosed the status of NAB approvals. Once operational, bilateral loan agreements will be integrated into the NAB. Approval for NAB resource use will change, with current requirements including approval from NAB participants and IMF Executive Board members. The United States does not have unilateral veto power under the current NAB. The expanded NAB requires approval from participants and the IMF Executive Board to be activated. The United States can unilaterally veto the activation of the NAB but cannot dictate or vote on which loans can be financed with NAB resources. The United States has subscribed $55 billion as its quota in the IMF since 1945. Since 1945, the United States has subscribed $55 billion as its quota in the IMF, with Congress authorizing and appropriating necessary funds for IMF funding agreements. The U.S. quota in the IMF serves as a line of credit available for IMF loans to borrower countries, with the IMF drawing on multiple countries' resources for funding. The IMF draws on resources from multiple countries to fund loans, including the U.S. The U.S. quota in the IMF is used as a line of credit for loans, with payments having no impact on the federal budget deficit. Congress approves U.S. participation and funds for IMF subscriptions, but does not have a role in individual loan approvals. Restrictions on how the IMF uses U.S. quota resources are not allowed. The IMF cannot use funds in ways that violate agreements. Congress may pass laws to oppose loans to specific countries or purposes, but the US alone cannot block IMF loan approvals. The US-EU economic relationship is the largest globally, with growing trade and financial activities. In 2009, $1,252.0 billion flowed between the US and the EU. The EU is the largest merchandise trading partner of the United States, accounting for a significant portion of U.S. exports and imports in 2009. Additionally, there was a substantial flow of direct investments between the U.S. and EU countries. U.S. financial institutions also had exposure through credit default swaps based on Greek sovereign debt. The value of the euro depreciated against the U.S. dollar due to investors losing confidence in the Eurozone. This led to a 21% decrease in the euro's value between December 2009 and June 2010. The weaker euro likely impacted U.S. exports to the Eurozone and increased U.S. imports from the Eurozone, widening the U.S. trade deficit. However, it made purchases and U.S. investments in Eurozone countries cheaper in dollar terms. The euro depreciated against the U.S. dollar, impacting U.S. exports and widening the trade deficit. The Chinese renminbi is tied to the dollar, affecting trade with Europe. The Greek crisis led investors to shift funds to U.S. Treasuries, causing yields to fall. The 10-year Treasury notes fell by half a percentage point, bringing interest rates from 4% in April 2010 to about 3% in mid-July. Lower interest rates benefit U.S. borrowers, including the U.S. Treasury and mortgage seekers. However, lower rates reduce yields for those relying on interest-bearing assets. Eurozone instability may lead to global credit market shrinkage and potential rise in interest rates, impacting the U.S. economy through various economic and financial linkages. The Eurozone instability affects U.S. exports, imports, and consumer confidence. It also impacts the price of oil and commodities, reducing the U.S. import bill for petroleum. However, it increases risk levels in debt and stock markets, potentially leading to volatility. A drop in equity values in the United States may reduce consumption and investment levels. Real U.S. GDP increased by $313.2 billion from first quarter 2009 to first quarter 2010, with increases in consumption, investment, net exports, and government expenditures. Lower interest rates and petroleum prices, along with increased risk and a weaker euro, may impact household consumption, the largest component of GDP. Lower interest rates are expected to boost pent-up demand for consumer durables, which were postponed during the recession. Consumption is projected to increase in line with GDP, with investments in new plant and equipment being crucial for U.S. recovery. However, business expectations of reduced export demand from Europe and the risk of a global slowdown may hinder new investments in production capacity. The first-time homebuyer tax credit expired in mid-2010, impacting housing demand. The drop in the euro's value and weakened Eurozone demand may increase the U.S. trade deficit. Government spending, except for lower interest rates, is not significantly affected by Eurozone instability. The overall impact on U.S. growth is uncertain, but IHS Global Insight believes the fallout from the Greek crisis will be relatively small for the United States. The Eurozone crisis is expected to dent the U.S. recovery but not derail it, with U.S. GDP growth rate projected to be in the 2.2% to 2.6% range during the second half of 2010. Various sources predict a lower growth rate for 2010, with factors beyond the Eurozone crisis also contributing to the reduced expectations. The Eurozone crisis is impacting U.S. growth, but other factors like the stimulus package winding down also play a role. Concerns arise about Greece's debt crisis mirroring the U.S.' future. Government debt sustainability depends on factors like exchange rate flexibility and debt maturity. Despite similarities in budget deficits, the U.S. may be in a stronger fiscal position due to factors like a floating exchange rate and the dollar's status as a reserve currency. The United States is considered a safe haven for investments, with U.S. bonds being attractive on international markets. The Senate passed the financial regulatory reform bill in 2010, which included an amendment restricting the use of federal funds for bailouts of foreign governments. The financial reform bill amendment directed the U.S. Executive Director at the IMF to evaluate loans to countries with public debt exceeding GDP, certify loan repayment to Congress, and oppose loans without certification. The impact was unclear, potentially affecting all heavily-indebted countries, including low-income ones. Several countries had public debt surpassing GDP in 2009, raising concerns about IMF aid during financial crises. The financial reform bill amendment requires U.S. representatives at the IMF to oppose loans to heavily indebted countries if repayment is unlikely. Low-income countries eligible for concessional aid are exempt. The Treasury Department must report regularly to Congress on conditions of countries receiving IMF loans despite U.S. opposition. The House is considering legislation related to debt management, including a bill requiring the Treasury Department to review IMF loans to countries with high public debt. Representative Mike Pence introduced the "European Bailout Protection Act" and Senator Jim DeMint introduced a companion bill to oppose funding through the New Arrangements to Borrow facility. The legislation introduced by Representative Mike Pence and Senator Jim DeMint aims to prevent the use of the expanded NAB facility to fund IMF loans for EU countries with high debt-to-GDP ratios. The United States can block the facility's activation by withholding support. Some concerns exist about unintended consequences of the legislation. The legislation introduced by Representative Mike Pence and Senator Jim DeMint aims to prevent the use of the expanded NAB facility to fund IMF loans for EU countries with high debt-to-GDP ratios. Concerns exist about unintended consequences of the legislation, such as blocking loans to European countries while allowing loans to other countries. The United States has the power to prevent the NAB from being activated but cannot veto specific borrowers. The legislation introduced by Representative Mike Pence and Senator Jim DeMint aims to prevent the use of the expanded NAB facility to fund IMF loans for EU countries with high debt-to-GDP ratios. The Secretary of the Treasury would need to keep the NAB shut indefinitely to avoid unexpected borrowing by EU countries. This legislation might also prevent existing bilateral lines of credit from being folded into the expanded NAB, potentially affecting the recent loan to Greece. Congress has not taken action on this legislation, but the Granger amendment to the pending fiscal 2011 Senate-Foreign Operations Appropriations bill uses a 60% threshold. The House Concurrent Resolution 279 seeks to disapprove U.S. participation in IMF funding for the EU unless each member country meets deficit spending and debt-to-GDP ratio criteria. The legislation aims to prevent U.S. resources from funding the European financial stability plan. It has been referred to the House Committee on Financial Services with no further action taken.
